deliberation: Most of the verse (God rejoicing in Jerusalem, absence of weeping) can be taken straightforwardly as describing divine emotion and social conditions. There is no distinct small-scale metaphor, simile, or idiom beyond general anthropomorphic language for God's rejoicing.

The verse describes remarkably long lifespans and the evaluation of a hundred-year-old as a 'youth.' It is visionary and may be idealized, but it functions as a straightforward eschatological description rather than a compact metaphor, simile, or idiom of the types requested.

The building of houses and planting of vineyards so as to enjoy their fruit is covenant-blessing language. It can serve as a concrete synecdoche for stable, secure life, but the verse itself reads as a direct promise without a clear, compact figurative expression distinguishable from literal meaning.
